narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled "NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants" expects to generate various types of scientific data, including demographic and clinical data (tabular) and MRI-based imaging data. The latter includes structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS, along with derived imaging measures/features and supporting documentation such as data dictionaries, protocols, and README files. Specifically, the dataset will comprise participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants (110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls) and multi-modal MRI imaging data. The total volume of data will depend on the imaging protocols used and the retained derivatives, with imaging data expected to be the largest component.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data will be de-identified prior to receipt by the repository. The information needed to generate a global unique identifier for the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) will be collected for each subject. These data will be preserved and shared because they are essential for facilitating research reproducibility, promoting data reuse, and advancing our understanding of the conditions under study. Sharing these data aligns with the principles of transparency and openness in scientific research.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata and associated documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, data collection instruments (e.g., questionnaires, clinical assessment tools), data dictionaries that describe the variables and their formats within the dataset, and README files explaining the contents and structure of the shared data. Additionally, any supporting documentation such as participant information sheets and informed consent forms will be available, ensuring that users of the shared data understand the context and conditions under which the data were collected.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate some of the shared scientific data, particularly the MRI imaging data. For example, software like FSL (FMRIB Software Library), AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages), or FreeSurfer may be required for processing and analyzing the structural and functional MRI data. These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories, and documentation on how to use them will be provided with the shared data.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. For the MRI imaging data, standards such as the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) recommendations will be followed. BIDS provides a simple and intuitive way to organize and describe neuroimaging data, making it easier for others to understand and reuse the shared data. For demographic and clinical data, standard formats and terminologies will be used where applicable, ensuring consistency and facilitating comparison across studies.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository that supports the sharing of human subjects data in mental health research. The NDA provides a secure and accessible platform for researchers to share their data, promoting collaboration and accelerating discovery.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the assignment of a persistent unique identifier (e.g., a DOI or a unique accession number provided by the NDA). This identifier will be linked to detailed metadata describing the dataset, including information about the study design, population, methods used for data collection and analysis, and any other relevant details. Users will be able to search for datasets using various criteria, such as keywords, study titles, or author names, facilitating the discovery of relevant data.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will remain accessible for a minimum of 10 years following the end of the project to allow for continued research and analysis by the scientific community.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Given that all research participants will provide broad consent for data sharing, there are minimal limitations on the access, distribution, or reuse of the scientific data. However, to protect participant privacy and confidentiality, all shared data will be de-identified, and access to certain sensitive information may be controlled.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be controlled for the majority of the dataset. However, for any components that require special handling due to sensitivity or privacy concerns, access may be managed through a controlled process by the NDA, requiring users to register and agree to terms of use before accessing the data.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: The privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants will be protected through de-identification of all shared data. This involves removing or modifying direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and indirect identifiers (e.g., dates of birth, ZIP codes) to minimize the risk of re-identification. Additionally, the project will comply with all relevant regulations and guidelines for human subjects research, including obtaining informed consent from participants for broad data sharing.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's principal investigator, in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. Regular reviews (at least annually) will be conducted to ensure that all data management and sharing activities are being performed according to the plan and any necessary adjustments are made. The oversight process includes verifying that data are properly de-identified before sharing, ensuring that metadata are accurately documented and updated, and monitoring user access and feedback to improve data sharing practices over time. This ongoing oversight is crucial for maintaining the integrity of the shared data and fostering a culture of transparency and collaboration within the research community.
